title: Victims of repeat burglaries rise by 16 per cent in a year as 'organised crime gangs exploits police gaps'
text:
Repeat victims of burglary have increased by more than 16 per cent in a year as criminals have exploited the decline in the police response, official figures show.

Data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) reveal the number of victims who had two or more burglaries in the past year rose from 60,188 to 70,277.

The biggest increase was among those had between two and four, which was up from 49,678 to 62,471, a 26 per cent rise.

Rick Muir, director of the independent Police Foundation, said: “One possible explanationis that organised crime groups have taken notice of the fact that the police response to burglaries has deteriorated.

“They could be doing more burglaries because they think they can get away with it because police are not able to investigate burglaries to the same extent that they used to.”

Only one in 20 burglaries (five per cent) in 2018/19 resulted in an offender being caught and charged, down from 9.3 per cent in 2014/15. In police forces with the lowest rates, there was a one in 30 chance of a burglar being charged.
